0.cdata!:
Mexico - Proyecto de ahorro y crédito
            popular y microfinanzas rurales : plan de desarrollo de
            pueblas indigenas

abstracts.cdata!:
The project will assist the Government
            of Mexico in strengthening the Savings and Credit
            Institutions sector with entities which are compliant with
            the Popular Savings and Credit Law, financially viable,
            operationally effective, managerially improved,
            technologically upgraded, and having an enhanced level of
            outreach and access to financial services by the underserved
            Mexican population. The National Development Plan of Mexico
            envisions the Mexican economy to demonstrate, among others,
            the two key attributes of human development and competitive
            growth. These two attributes are represented in the three
            objectives of: (a) increasing and expanding competitiveness;
            (b) promoting balanced regional development that includes
            all population segments; and (c) increasing equity and
            equality of opportunity. The 2004 Country Assistance
            Strategy (FY 2005 through FY 2008) supports the Mexican
            governments efforts to achieve these three objectives
            through initiatives under the two broad themes of: (a)
            reducing poverty and inequality; and (b) increasing
            competitiveness. The project is essentially a technical
            assistance project. No negative impact is foreseen; rather
            the project is expected to benefit some of the savings and
            credit sector entities operating in marginal areas (which
            are identical to the ones in the ongoing project) where
            indigenous population is high. The project will continue to
            assist about 195 entities, some of which are in the marginal
            areas, and for which indigenous population aspects are
            already being addressed under the on-going project. It will
            assist about 45 new entities, very few of which may be
            situated in the identified marginal areas. No indirect or
            long-term negative impacts are expected as a result of
            project activities. The technical assistance is expected to
            deepen the outreach of the assisted entities, and will
            improve access to financial services in the underserved
            areas in Mexico, benefiting all categories of populations.
